) Change to Title. Changed title from Partnership Control System (PCS) to Pass-Through Control System (PCS). PCS is used to manage S-corporations as well as partnerships. Pass-through is more reﬂective of the systems function. (

) Editorial changes throughout. Updated terminology used, and removed italics from titles. Campus TEFRA Function (CTF) to Campus Pass-through Function (CPF). Some references to remain as PCS programming has not yet changed. Spelled out ﬁrst use of acronyms.

Change to Title. Changed title from Partnership Control System (PCS) to Pass-Through Control System (PCS). PCS is used to manage S-corporations as well as partnerships. Pass-through control is more reﬂective of the systems function.

Editorial changes throughout. Updated terminology used, and removed italics from titles. Changed Campus TEFRA Function (CTF) to Campus Pass-through Function (CPF). Some references to CTF remain as PCS programming has not yet changed. Spelled out ﬁrst use of acronyms.
EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS

This material supersedes IRM 4.29.3, dated 11-27-2017. Changes to this IRM will also affect the Pass- Through Entity Handbook, IRM 4.31 Sections 1 through 8. That IRM is currently being rewritten and will include the changes contained in this IRM.
Field and campus personnel working TEFRA and ILSC pass-through entities and/or their investors.
Table of Contents
Database Elements
) This Internal Revenue Manual (IRM) section provides an explanation of different elements of the Pass-Through Control System (PCS) database. Scope and (
) Purpose: This IRM is to describe the unique PCS database elements. (
) Audience: Field Examination Revenue Agents (RAs) and campus RAs, Compliance Offers (TCOs), Tax Examiners (TEs) and Clerks working pass- through entities and/or their investors linked on PCS. (
) Policy Owner: Director, Small Business/Self-Employed (SB/SE), ters, Examination Field and Campus Policy (SE:S:E:HQ:EFCP) (
) Program Owner: Program Manager, Campus Examination and Field (SE:S:E:HQ:EFCP:CEFS) (
) Primary Stakeholders: SB/SE, Large Business and Industry (LB&I), and Appeals (

) Program Goals: PCS is a database used to create an electronic linkage between pass-through entities and their underlying partners. Linking in instances is mandatory. Linkage allows for the proper control of statutes ensures all relevant partners are processed. (
) Contact Information: To recommend changes or make any other related to this IRM section, see IRM
, Providing Feedback About IRM Section -Outside of Clearance. (

) PCS was created to monitor and control pass-through entity investors. through entities can have many partners and many levels of tiering. Tiering occurs when an investor in a pass-through entity is also a pass-through This complexity can make it difficult to keep track of statutes and monitor the investors. (

) PCS control is a policy that was established in response to the partnership provisions of the Tax Equity and Fiscal Responsibility Act (TEFRA) of has been expanded to cover other pass-through entities that fall outside of TEFRA. (

) The Director, SB/SE, Headquarters, Examination Field and Campus Policy (SE:S:E:HQ:EFCP) is responsible for: or a. Coordinating and implementing PCS enhancements; and b. Coordinating resolutions for PCS systemic problems; and c. Updating this Handbook. (

) The SB/SE Program Manager, Examination Field and Campus Policy, Exam & Field Support (SE:S:E:HQ:EFCP:CEFS) is responsible for: a. Ensuring that PCS procedural changes and computer program are implemented and coordinated with area office and campus tion personnel; and b. Monitoring and evaluating area office and campus examination PCS quality control procedures. (
) Field Territory Managers, Field Area Directors, Director over LB&I Ogden Director, Examination - Brookhaven, are responsible for ensuring that:

) Internal Revenue Manual
Policy Owner: Director, Small Business/Self-Employed (SB/SE), Headquar- ters, Examination Field and Campus Policy (SE:S:E:HQ:EFCP)
The SB/SE Program Manager, Examination Field and Campus Policy, Campus Exam & Field Support (SE:S:E:HQ:EFCP:CEFS) is responsible for:

Ensuring that PCS procedural changes and computer program are implemented and coordinated with area office and campus tion personnel; and Monitoring and evaluating area office and campus examination PCS quality control procedures.
Field Territory Managers, Field Area Directors, Director over LB&I Ogden and Director, Examination - Brookhaven, are responsible for ensuring that:

Pass-Through Control a. An accurate database is established by designating PCS and activities; and b. A PCS quality control system is implemented. This includes timely on PCS record establishments, PCS reports, and AIMS TC
Reject Registers. It also includes timely processing of TEFRA notices and Appeals settlement letters (campus only). (
) Area office Examination Managers and campus Field Support Operations managers are responsible for: a. Maintaining an updated copy of IRM

, Pass-Through Control (PCS) Handbook, in their respective functions; b. Ensuring the training of technical and clerical employees in PCS dures; and c. Establishing PCS records and acting on PCS reports in a timely to assure an accurate PCS database. (
) The campus PCS Coordinator works with: • The other PCS coordinator(s) • Their local employees • Other campus functional areas to ensure timely processing of PCS related activities (
) The campus PCS Coordinator is charged with: • Identifying and resolving technical problems • Identifying and coordinating the resolution of PCS systemic problems (

) Following are speciﬁc campus PCS Coordinator responsibilities: a. Coordinate PCS operations among areas, Campus Pass-through Functions (CPFs), and other campus functions; b. Ensure timely processing and distribution of PCS output; c. Ensure that all requests for establishment and linkage on PCS are reviewed for accuracy, completeness, and timeliness; d. Maintain accuracy of the PCS database by ensuring that action and reports are worked in required time frames; e. Resolve Audit Information Management System (AIMS) problems; f. Assist in the training of examination personnel in PCS procedures and system; g. Establish and update CPF and Appeals parameter ﬁles; h. Review completed Form
, PCS Notice Parameters, prepared by CPF and Appeals; i. Create, load, print, proofread, and edit parameter ﬁle data using Form

, PCS Notice Parameters; j. Coordinate with Computer Systems Analyst (CSA) whenever a change made to parameters; k. Review and input all campus Command Code (CC) Mass Change ( MSCHG) and linkage deletion (TSDEL) requests; l. Coordinate requests for PCS IVLs with campus computer services and requesting function.
4.29 Pass-Through Control System

An accurate database is established by designating PCS responsibilities and activities; and A PCS quality control system is implemented. This includes timely action on PCS record establishments, PCS reports, and AIMS TC
Reject Registers. It also includes timely processing of TEFRA notices and Appeals settlement letters (campus only).

Following are speciﬁc campus PCS Coordinator responsibilities: a. Coordinate PCS operations among areas, Campus Pass-through Functions (CPFs), and other campus functions; b. Ensure timely processing and distribution of PCS output; c. Ensure that all requests for establishment and linkage on PCS are reviewed for accuracy, completeness, and timeliness; d. Maintain accuracy of the PCS database by ensuring that action and reports are worked in required time frames; e. Resolve Audit Information Management System (AIMS) problems; f. Assist in the training of examination personnel in PCS procedures and system; g. Establish and update CPF and Appeals parameter ﬁles; h. Review completed Form
, PCS Notice Parameters, prepared by the CPF and Appeals; i. Create, load, print, proofread, and edit parameter ﬁle data using Form

, PCS Notice Parameters; j. Coordinate with Computer Systems Analyst (CSA) whenever a change is made to parameters; k. Review and input all campus Command Code (CC) Mass Change ( MSCHG) and linkage deletion (TSDEL) requests; l. Coordinate requests for PCS IVLs with campus computer services and the requesting function.

4.29 Pass-Through Control System

) The PCS database contains commonly known database elements of the AIMS ﬁle such as taxpayer name, tax period, taxpayer address, Taxpayer Identiﬁca- tion Number (TIN), Master File Tax Account Code (MFT), statute date, etc. (
) This section discusses PCS database elements that are not found on the other systems. See Exhibit

, Location of PCS Database Elements, lists where the unique PCS database elements appear within the PCS. Understand- ing these unique PCS database elements enables the user to properly use the PCS for controlling and processing TEFRA and ILSC accounts. (
) This section also covers: • TEFRA action elements • ILSC action elements • Record indicators • Other unique PCS database elements
• Other unique PCS database elements Note: The term campus refers to both Brookhaven and LB&I Pass-through (PTE) Ogden. (
) These elements are unique to the PCS. (

) The elements in this sub-section relate to assessment statute date, assess- ment amount and time spent on case. (

) The one-year assessment statute date is the date by which the Service make the TEFRA assessment to the individual investor, without securing a statute extension which properly extends the TEFRA statute. (
) The one year assessment statute date is manually input to the PCS record via Form
(CC TSCHG) or Form
(CC TSCHGM). (
) Once the TEFRA assessment is made, the one-year assessment statute must be updated to “
” and the Assessment Amount and Report Time Fields must be input. This update shows that the assessment on this TEFRA issue was made. (
) When

s are overwriting an existing one-year assessment date and tiering exists, a warning message will appear but the input will be allowed. message will appear as follows: WARNING: PS RECORD HAS TIERING - TRANSACTION COMPLETE. PS stands for pass-through. (

J. This will allow the campuses to track those partners that are in suspense pending a ﬁnal decision by the District Court or Court of Claims.

) The one-year assessment date will be entered as follows:
-MMDDYYYYA, where A is the Investor Closing Code. The Investor Closing Code is not entered when inputting the
s along with the assessment and time information, it is only used when inputting the actual OYD. (

) CC TSCHGM can be used to input the one-year date (OYD) and Investor Closing Code on multiple investors. However, care should be taken to all investors are subject to the same Investor Closing Code. CC TSCHG M not overwrite any existing codes, it will only ﬁll in blank ﬁelds. (
) The Investor Closing Code can be updated or changed by entering a CC TSCHG item
with the correct code. (
) The Investor Closing Code will be removed when a
-T or
-D is input CC TSCHG. (

CC MSCHG can also be used to change already existing Investor Closing Codes. CC MSCHG will not update blank ﬁelds.
Pass-Through Control (

) When issuing a Statutory Notice of Deﬁciency to an investor due to affected items or if assessing penalties determined at the partner level, a penalty indicator must be input onto the system. This is done by entering the OYD followed by a “P”. (
) The “P” can only be entered if a OYD was already on the system for the investor, and the TEFRA assessment information was input. The new OYD with the penalty indicator replaces the
s that were input following the TEFRA assessment. The OYD date with the “P” indicator is input as
- MMDDYYYYXP, where “X” is Investor Closing Code and “P” is the Penalty Indicator. (
) The Investor Closing Code is entered when the OYD is input the ﬁrst time. Investor Closing Code can be found on CC TSINQ if it is needed. (
) CC TSCHGM cannot be used to add the penalty indicator. (
) The amount of each TEFRA assessment must be input using CC TSCHG, when change item
is used to update the one-year assessment statute to “

”. This entry must be immediately followed by the dollar sign ($) and the whole dollar amount of the assessed deﬁciency, or the whole dollar amount of an overassessment followed by a minus sign (-). The assessment amount may be one to twelve digits. Larger assessments must be entered separately. (
) If the TEFRA examination results in no change to the investor return, enter after
) If the investor is a tier return, enter TIER after
) If the TEFRA examination results in a change to the taxable income on the investor return, but no change is made in the amount of tax, enter CNC after
) The assessment amount includes the additional tax from the TEFRA adjust- ments and DOES NOT include any assessed penalties. DO NOT include Tax Motivated Transaction (TMT) interest or TC
interest in this amount. (
) Penalty assessment amounts must be entered after the Penalty Assessment Indicator has been entered on the system. See IRM
, Penalty Assessment Indicator, above. (

) Caution must be taken when processing an assessment made up of more one key case adjustment. Each assessment from a key case adjustment be accounted for separately. They must not be lumped together in order to ensure the data is reported correctly, CC TSCHG will generate an on screen warning when the investor has more than one linkage to remind the person inputting the amounts to check for assessments from more than one key The error will read, “WARNING: PN REC HAS >
KEY CASE LINKS. ENSURE TAX IS PROPERLY SPLIT BETWEEN KEY CASES”. (

) If a tier is subject to more than one one-year assessment date, an existing one-year date being overwritten by a new one-year date will result in the following message: WARNING: PS RECORD HAS TIERING - COMPLETE. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

The Investor Closing Code is entered when the OYD is input the ﬁrst time. The Investor Closing Code can be found on CC TSINQ if it is needed.
Assessment Amount

In addition to the assessment dollars or appropriate literal, the update to “11111111” requires input of the total processing time. Total processing time is the accumulation of all time spent on processing the case. All technical report writing time should be included on the Form 8339. This ﬁeld requires a “T” followed by the processing time expressed in tenths of hours:
Note: The maximum time allowed is 999.9. Any additional time must be entered on a separate Form 8339.
Note: Time is not entered on Appeals cases.
) The OYD information must be removed when an investor has another linkage. If the investor will be partially closed due to another linkage, PCS record needs to be cleared. (

Pass-Through Control (

) Record Indicators are database elements that notify users that there is a unique relationship between the PCS record and other databases or ﬁles of Record (AIMS) or between one PCS record and another. (
) The record indicators are displayed to assist the user in obtaining on the account for processing purposes. (
) The
indicator indicates that a full record has not established on AIMS. (
) When the

indicator appears on the PCS record, only AIMS status special project code, name control, source code, employee group code, MFT, tax period, primary business code, and activity code are displayed PCS record. (
) The AIMS name and statute date for the account will not appear on the until the record is fully established on AIMS. (
) The Partnership Investor Control File (PICF) indicator prevents an AIMS account from closing until all linkage record freezes are released using CC Investor TSCLS. See text at IRM
, Establishing ILSC and TEFRA File (PICF) Investor Records, of this Handbook for information on CC TSCLS. (
) The PICF indicator is automatically set on the AIMS record by establishing record on the PCS. See Exhibit
, PICF Indicator Codes and tions, for a list with deﬁnitions for the PICF indicator codes. (
) The PICF indicator appears on an AIMS AMDISA display by the literal Code X on page

) The clean case indicator identiﬁes investor accounts with only one open linkage record. This information is useful when determining the Case Indicator of returns, not linkages, that may close. This information is used when the closed returns objective is determined for each CPF. (
) The clean case indicator considers a linkage open if: a. The key case is a TEFRA entity (PICF
), and there is no one-year sessment statute date, or b. The key case is a ILSC entity (PICF
), and the key case is in an status code below
) The clean case indicator appears as “*” on PCS Reports
, and
) The TEFRA indicator identiﬁes key case, tier, and other investor records TEFRA or ILSC. Indicator (

) The TEFRA indicator appears on the key case, tier, and other investor as a “T” on PCS reports. On CC TSINQ the literal “TEFRA” is followed by literal “YES” if the pass-through record (PS) or partner record (PN) is If the PS or PN is ILSC, the literal “NO” appears after TEFRA. On a screen the TEFRA indicator is “T”. The literal “TEFRA” is not displayed. (
) TEFRA indicators are set on the PCS records using Form
, PCS Establish or Add, and Form
, PCS Establish or Add, when T is

The clean case indicator appears as “*” on PCS Reports 21–2, 22–2, and
TEFRA indicators are set on the PCS records using Form 8340, PCS TEFRA Establish or Add, and Form 8341, PCS Establish or Add, when T is entered in
the TEFRA indicator ﬁeld. It can also be added or deleted using Form
, PCS Change, item
or Form
, Mass Change, item
) Removal of the TEFRA indicator on an investor’s linkage record excludes report writing accomplishments from PCS Reports
A, and

Normally, the only situations that require the removal of the “T” indicator are when the CPF is notiﬁed or becomes aware of a bankruptcy proceeding or after coordination with Criminal Investigation when a TC
freeze is It will also be removed if partnership items are converted to nonpartnership items, unless it is due to a settlement. (
) If the TEFRA indicator was removed from an investor’s linkage record, no TEFRA notices will generate. (
) The tier indicator identiﬁes investor records that are pass-through entities. These records appear in the PCS as a key case record and as an investor record. (
) The tier indicator appears as a pound sign “#”, “P” (Parent), “S” (Subsidiary) “X” (No Load) on PCS reports, and CC TSINQ and CC TSUMY terminal displays. (
) PCS Report
, No Load Report, shows the number of tier returns with a load indicator. PCS Report
, Unperfected Tier Report, shows the number tiers without a tier indicator. (

) The affected item/ partner level penalty report indicator identiﬁes one-year sessment statute dates that are present only for penalty, or other affected items, purposes. The information is used in monitoring TEFRA OYDs on the PCS

Report. When the indicator is present, it alerts the CPFs to the that the one-year assessment statute date is for a penalty and/or an item issue, and that the TEFRA tax adjustment issue is already complete. (
) The penalty/affected item report indicator “P” is input along with the OYD the TEFRA assessment is made. a. The
s must be present in the one-year date ﬁeld before the penalty and/or affected item date and the “P” date can be input. b. Overlay the
s with the penalty and/or affected item date, Closing Code and the “P”. c. This allows the TEFRA assessment to remain on the PCS and be extracted to the accomplishment tables. (
) The penalty/affected item report indicator is displayed on PCS reports and TSINQ and TSUMY screens immediately after the one-year assessment statute date, i.e., MMDDYYYYXP (
XP) (Where X = the Investor Closing Code) (
) The indicator causes penalty/affected item records to sort to separate on PCS Report
, and that allows monitoring of the penalty/affected item one-year assessment statute dates separately from the TEFRA one-year sessment statute dates. Caution: The Taxpayer Relief Act of
changed how penalties are reﬂected the key case (also tier) RAR. For report writing and assessment purposes, penalties are treated like partnership items for years ending Internal Revenue Manual
The tier indicator identiﬁes investor records that are pass-through entities. These records appear in the PCS as a key case record and as an
The tier indicator appears as a pound sign “#”, “P” (Parent), “S” (Subsidiary) or “X” (No Load) on PCS reports, and CC TSINQ and CC TSUMY terminal
(03-01-2006) Affected Item/ Partner Level Penalty Report Indicator
4.29 Pass-Through Control System
after August 5, 1997, the date of enactment of TRA ’97. Penalties need to be input separately for the regular audit adjustments.
There are ﬁve different penalty/affected item codes. Each code has a signiﬁ
cant meaning and causes different notices and attachments to be generated. The codes A, P, and X are all applied at the key case level. The codes have the following signiﬁcance:

Blank – No attachments needed A – Affected items apply to the investors D – Deletes any existing TEFRA Penalty/Affected Item code and returns to blank. P – Penalties apply to adjustments X – Penalties apply to adjustments, and there are affected items.
The notice codes will cause the generation of the following notices:
Penalty/ Package type Notice Attachment Affected Item Code 60 Day 870 Blank N/A –PT Blank FPAA 870 N/A –PT A (for affected 60 Day 870-LT N/A item) A (for affected FPAA 870 E item) –PT
Note: D is used to remove any existing TEFRA Penalty/Affected Item code and return the ﬁeld to Blank.
Note: The settlement Forms
-PT/LT generated by PCS will be coded to whether it was generated with a
-Day letter or an FPAA. If the settlement form was generated with a
-Day letter there will be a “
” in the upper hand corner of the letter under the revision date. Similarly there will be an “FP” in the same location if the agreement was generated with an FPAA. (
) The notice code must be present on the key case record for the PCS to generate the appropriate settlement agreements and attachments. (
) The attachments are generated with FPAAs where partner level affected or penalties apply.

Note: The settlement Forms 870-PT/LT generated by PCS will be coded to identity whether it was generated with a 60-Day letter or an FPAA. If the settlement form was generated with a 60-Day letter there will be a “60” in the upper left hand corner of the letter under the revision date. Similarly there will be an
The attachments are generated with FPAAs where partner level affected items
Elements
page • Attachment E explains that affected items are applicable at the level and will be assessed though a separate notice. (
) The notice code is displayed on CC TSINQ and CC TSUMY screens, PCS Reports
, and National Directory Reports (Reports
and

) Indicates that all pass-throughs that are linked to the investor have been closed. This is determined by checking the PN CLSD PS IND of the linkage Indicator records which are linked to the investor. CC TSCLS sets it to closed if there are no more open linkages. (

) The TEFRA Indicator is displayed on the CC TSUMYP screen and the Sum Closed Indicator is displayed on the CC TSUMYI screen. This ﬁeld is in the same place but depending on whether the deﬁner is a “P” or “I”. (

) The partnership assessment amount is an accumulation of all assessments made at the partner level as the result of adjustments made at the Assessment level. The assessment amount is recorded on PCS by the input of CC item
on an investor. The amount of the assessment input on the partner added to the last partnership assessment amount. (

) If a report is being processed which has more than one key case adjustment passing to the taxpayer, then each assessment must be entered separately. the incorrect amount is entered when inputting an assessment amount, the amount needs to be corrected. CC TSINQP needs to be researched to determine the Partnership Assessment amount. This is the accumulation of partner assessments related to the key case. To correct this amount, the correct accumulated amount needs to be entered using CC TSCHG item
For example, if a CC TSCHG item

assessment was entered that reﬂected assessments from two different key cases, then the amount of the overstate- ment needs to be backed out of the Partnership Assessment Amount for the key case entered on the Form
, PCS Change. A CC TSINQ be reviewed to determine the current total in the Partnership Assessment amount. If the Partnership Assessment amount is $
, and the amount the overstatement is $
, then a CC TSCHG item
entry of $
needs to be made to reset the Partnership Assessment amount total to the correct amount. This entry should only be made by the PCS Coordinator. (
) This amount can be viewed using CC TSINQP. (
) The partnership adjustment amount reﬂects the amount of adjustment made the partnership level. This amount is input using CC TSCHG item
when Adjustment key case Notice/Closing package is received from the Technical Services (Field) TEFRA Coordinator. (
) The CC TSCHG
must be entered before a CC TSNOT can be input to generate a
-day Letter or an FPAA. Note: A CC TSCHG
should be entered for all key cases being adjusted, both TEFRA, Tier and ILSC. (

) The amount to enter as the adjustment amount will vary. As a rule, all ments should be combined to arrive at one net adjustment. Adjustments to credits will be divided by
% (credit amount /
% = credit adjustment amount). This will allow credits and ordinary income/expense adjustments be combined without skewing the results due to the credits. (
) This amount can be viewed using CC TSINQP. (
) The following sub-sections discuss additional database elements that apply a record. (
) The PCS provides a unique ﬁeld to add an optional message to a linked record. Up to
characters, letters or numbers, can be used. “Sub. of (TIN Message parent company)” is an example. (
) User special messages for key case or investor records are added and updated using Form
, PCS Change, item
, and appear on the CC TSINQ display. (

) The package received date is the date the report package is received by campus. The report package received date can be input by CCs TSCHG, TSCHGM or MSCHG. If input via CCs MSCHG or TSCHGM, the Report Package Indicator Code will automatically be input on all investors by the campus initiating the CC MSCHG or TSCHGM. If input by CC the Report Package Received Indicator Code and Report Package Date will have to be updated separately. (
) The Report Package Received Indicator Code is input by CC TSCHG (item using Form
, PCS Change, when the investor campus receives the complete report writing package. An incorrect report package received can be removed by inputting a “D” in item
) When the report writing package is received in the CPF, the Report Received Indicator Code is immediately updated to “Y”. If input using CC TSCHG, item
, then the Report Package Received Date must also be updated using CC TSCHG, item
This prevents requests to the key case CPF for report packages that were received in the investor CPF, but were associated with the investor returns. (
) CC TSCHGM can be used to input the Report Package Received Date. Report Package Received Indicator will automatically be updated to a “Y”. (
) The report package received indicator ﬁeld for the investor linkage record is also used to indicate that the return is not under control of the CPF or the statute was protected. See Exhibit

) The following elements discuss automatic system actions that are time sensitive. (
) The purge date is the date that a record drops off the PCS database. The purge date is automatically set to two months beyond the date that AIMS status code
went on the account. (

s for the status code

drop date is removed. The

) The bankruptcy indicator identiﬁes records of investors who have ﬁled for bankruptcy. a. The indicator is automatically input on the PCS for investors that AIMS weekly updates for bankruptcy. b. It may also be input manually by either the investor CPF or the key CPF that receives information of a bankrupt investor. (
) The bankruptcy indicator is displayed on PCS Reports
as a “B” in the appropriate ﬁeld. The indicator causes the records to appear on separate pages of Report

This allows the CPFs to statute control of bankrupt taxpayers. a. Records that have the bankruptcy indicator present and the report package received indicator code is other than “B” will be listed sepa- rately. These cases will be listed even when the one-year Internal Revenue Manual
The tracking code is a four digit code. This code can now be added as part of CC TSLOD and can be applied to campus controlled investors.
The settlement date is the date the settlement agreement is countersigned for the Service on behalf of the Commissioner by the designated official.
The date must be entered within 14 days of execution for the Commissioner.

Pass-Through Control statute date ﬁeld is blank. This list has priority over all other lists. It sents investors that are identiﬁed as bankrupt on AIMS, but are not identiﬁed as bankrupt on PCS. b. This represents investors that were identiﬁed as bankrupt on AIMS and identiﬁed as bankrupt on PCS. (
) The bankruptcy indicator is displayed on CCs TSUMYI and TSINQI screens the literal bankrupt. (

) The indicator appears on the CC TSUMYP as the literal “BKRPT” or “BKRPT RP=X” in lieu of the investor’s name. a. Records with the literal “BKRPT” are bankrupt investors that have the bankruptcy indicator present and also have a “B” in the report package received ﬁeld. This indicates that the ﬁle is controlled for bankruptcy purposes by the investor CPF or the ﬁeld office. b. Records with the literal “BKRPT RP=X” have the bankruptcy indicator present but the literal in the report package area is not “B”. This that the ﬁle is not controlled for bankruptcy purposes by the investor or ﬁeld office. (

) This element identiﬁes the campus controlling the key case and the investors. When the CPF or PTE inputs the TSLOD for the key case, PCS assigns the appropriate CTF indicator. Brookhaven is assigned a “B” and Ogden is assigned an “O”. Note: PCS has not yet been reprogrammed to change CTF to CPF. PCS will be changed to reﬂect to a CPF indicator in a future update. (

) The CTF indicator can be found on CC TSINQ. This allows the ﬁeld and appeals offices to identify the controlling campus in the event the need to forward a return. The standard “B” or “O” code is displayed as “BSC” or for simplicity. (
) CC TSCHG and CC TSCHGM can be used by the campus to change the indicator in the event it is not correct, or an investor gets transferred between campuses. (
) It is important that the CTF indicator be correct. The PCS reports use CTF indicator to determine which campus the data is reported. (
) Appeals has special instructions for identifying the proper campus. Because Appeals cases are controlled under the a

xx PBC, systemically determining the controlling campus is not as easy. As a result, the computer defaults ownership to BSC if it cannot determine the proper owner. If the CC TSINQ an Appeals case displays a CTF indicator of BSC, then a CC TXMODC must be pulled to ensure that Brookhaven controls the case. (
